Congressman Tom Emmer Tackles the War on Crypto

Representative Tom Emmer is a U.S. Representative for Minnesota, and is the serving House Majority Whip as of this year, making him one of the highest-ranking members of the U.S. House of Representatives. He has been an outspoken advocate of crypto and has rung the alarm bells as to what seems to be the politically-driven debanking of crypto in the United States of America.  ------ 📣 Infur

Representative Tom Emmer is a U.S. Representative for Minnesota, and is the serving House Majority Whip as of this year, making him one of the highest-ranking members of the U.S. House of Representatives. He has been an outspoken advocate of crypto and has rung the alarm bells as to what seems to be the politically-driven debanking of crypto in the United States of America.

Nym - Medium

Nym token economics: quarterly parameter update

It is that time again folks! The mixnet token economic parameters are being updated to take into account the recent vest. The vest means there are now more NYM tokens in circulation, thereby increasing the total available staking supply. This requires a new target staking supply and, of particular interest to stakers and mix node operators, this means the stake saturation point increases to

It is that time again folks! The mixnet token economic parameters are being updated to take into account the recent vest.

The vest means there are now more NYM tokens in circulation, thereby increasing the total available staking supply. This requires a new target staking supply and, of particular interest to stakers and mix node operators, this means the stake saturation point increases to 929k NYM.

Here is a quick overview:

New parameters Circulating supply: 394 million NYM Locked token that can be staked: 52 million NYM Max staking supply: 446 million NYM Target staking supply: 223 million Mix node stake saturation point: 929k NYM

For those wondering what lies behind these numbers and why the parameters change, here is a little recap…

Why do Nym token economic parameters change?

With every new vest, a tranche of tokens are released and become part of the circulating supply. This means the tokens that are available to be staked on mix nodes increase, changing the token economic parameters.

With the latest vest, the total circulating supply has increased to 394million and the locked tokens that are available to be staked are 52million. This gives a total of 446million that in theory could be staked.

Taking into account current levels of staking, we set the target to 50% of the available staking supply of 446 million NYM, leading to a current target staking supply of 223million. The target staking supply determines the mix node stake saturation point.

Mix nodes have a stake saturation point, which is the amount of stake that maximises the node’s rewards. This parameter is found by dividing the target staking supply by the number of rewarded nodes per epoch (currently 240 nodes).

With these new parameters, the APY of well-performing nodes with high levels of staking is slightly above 20%.

The next update to this parameter will take place in June after the next quarterly vest.

Join the Nym community of stakers and mix node operators

Telegram // Discord // Twitter

Nym token economics: quarterly parameter update was originally published in nymtech on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

Jim Bianco is the Head of Bianco Research and owner of BiancoResearch.ETH, Jim is our go-to source of macro analysis from someone who also knows crypto. 

Jim was early and loud about the initial Fed pivot into rising interest rates, all the way back in March of 2022, before much of the crypto industry really understood how significant interest rates can be. 

Now, we’re having Jim back on for his 4th time to help us navigate this next wave of macro chaos.

Verida

Revolutionizing Web3 Storage: A Deep Dive into IPFS and Verida DbStore

In today’s digital world, data storage is a crucial component for all applications, regardless of their scope or complexity. While traditional Web2 offers a wealth of storage options tailored to various use cases, such as SQL, NoSQL, Filestorage, S3, and FTP, the transition to Web3 demands a similar expansion of storage infrastructure to accommodate its unique requirements. IPFS has emerged as th

In today’s digital world, data storage is a crucial component for all applications, regardless of their scope or complexity. While traditional Web2 offers a wealth of storage options tailored to various use cases, such as SQL, NoSQL, Filestorage, S3, and FTP, the transition to Web3 demands a similar expansion of storage infrastructure to accommodate its unique requirements.

IPFS has emerged as the de-facto standard for storing data in Web3, with its decentralized file storage protocol being ideal for images, videos, and static content. However, IPFS was never designed to handle personal data, and thus, a more suitable solution is necessary.

Enter Verida DbStore, the first “self-sovereign” database infrastructure for Web3, which promises to revolutionize how data is managed by offering users guaranteed ownership, the speed and performance of traditional databases, and the ability to permanently delete their data. As a new decentralized infrastructure and architecture, Verida DbStore is specifically designed for rapid access to highly changing, structured personal data with encryption as a fundamental aspect of the protocol.

Let’s delve into the intricacies of IPFS and Verida DbStore, comparing their architecture, security, performance, storage types, and suitability for handling personally identifiable information (PII).

At a glance: IPFS vs Verida DbStore Architecture

IPFS consists of a peer-to-peer (P2P) network of block storage nodes, where each node is responsible for data identified by its unique hash. Users can retrieve data from any node, which collaborates with other nodes to locate and return the requested information.

IPFS consists of a peer-to-peer (P2P) network of block storage nodes

On the other hand, Verida is a P2P network of database storage nodes, each responsible for a user-specific queryable database. Data on the network is identified by the owner and database name. To retrieve data, users look up the database storage nodes associated with a user and request the data from one or more nodes. Data is replicated across multiple nodes based on geographical and user preferences.

With Verida, a user can use their private key to sign, encrypt and access their data Type of storage

IPFS stores unstructured blobs of data such as images, videos or PDFs.

Verida stores structured data in a document database that can be queried, indexed and replicated.

Security

IPFS lacks native authentication or encryption, making all stored data publicly accessible without permissions or security restrictions, akin to a globally distributed hard drive with universal read access.

In contrast, Verida incorporates end-to-end encryption as a fundamental aspect of its protocol. All data requires authorization for access and a decryption key, ensuring security on par with traditional database infrastructure. Verida also offers flexible permission configuration for each user database, allowing control over read, write, update, and delete permissions.

Performance

IPFS, inspired by torrenting technology, uses distributed hash tables to find content across nodes. While this allows for fast read responses when data is cached locally, it leads to significant latency in discovering new data, resulting in unpredictable and slow response times. This latency issue makes IPFS unsuitable for dynamically changing data without additional protocols.

Real world data from Cloudflare showing an average response time of 44.4 seconds for newly created content on IPFS.

In contrast, Verida is designed for sub-second reads and writes. Although there’s some initial overhead in discovering a user’s database, once connected, data transfer occurs via a P2P socket connection. This makes Verida ideal for applications requiring “web2-like” performance, where interactions are primarily “app-to-user” or “user-to-user.”

Suitable for PII

Personally Identifiable Information (PII) includes sensitive data like health records, names, addresses, and financial records that are legally protected in most countries. Regulations dictate the storage, transfer, and user rights concerning PII.

IPFS, a globally decentralized network, is unsuitable for storing PII because it offers no control over data storage or replication, nor guarantees data deletion, which is necessary for compliance with the “right to be forgotten” in many jurisdictions.

Verida DbStore, also a globally decentralized network, allows users to control where their data is stored. By default, the Verida Wallet selects storage nodes in the user’s country or region, ensuring regulatory compliance. Users can change these nodes or host their own for greater self-sovereignty. They can also delete their data from storage nodes, delete their identity and data entirely, and exercise their “right to be forgotten.” Verida combines the advantages of decentralization with regulatory compliance.

The Verida Client SDK is designed to empower user’s to control where their data is stored. IPFS as a base layer

Numerous projects are developing decentralized database infrastructure for Web3 using IPFS, including Textile, Ceramic, and Web5. At first glance, this approach may appear logical, as IPFS serves as the filesystem for Web3 and could potentially be transformed into a queryable database. However, this strategy proves to be impractical.

This approach is similar to constructing a permissioned, encrypted MySQL on a public S3 bucket. This would be slow and vulnerable to security threats, making it an undesirable option. While some projects incorporate an encryption layer over IPFS, the eventual breaking of current encryption would leave the data exposed, as it is both public and permanently accessible. In contrast, Verida safeguards encrypted data through authentication and authorization layers, adhering to industry best practices for protecting sensitive information.

To address these issues, some projects introduce additional server-side infrastructure on top of IPFS, forming new “storage networks.” However, if extra infrastructure is necessary, it would be more efficient to build on a foundation designed as a database from the outset, rather than relying on an ill-suited base technology like IPFS.

It is essential to note that IPFS is suitable for various use cases, such as storing immutable public records, NFT images or videos, or whitepaper PDFs. However, it is not an ideal choice for personal data storage, which necessitates a more fitting alternative.

Verida’s approach

At Verida, we’ve adopted a groundbreaking approach by creating nodes that are not based on IPFS, but rather on well-established database technology that supports authorization, permissions, and decentralized identity standards. This innovative strategy combines the best of both worlds: the reliability of battle-tested, industry-leading database technology and seamless integration with emerging decentralized identity standards through our provided SDKs and server components.

In a world where users can own their personal data, it’s critical to provide a mechanism to share encrypted data with third parties. The Verida protocol leverages encrypted data replication which is facilitated by peer-to-peer database synchronization at the protocol level.

This standards based architecture allows for the addition of various storage engines, making Verida DbStore the first of many decentralized storage solutions expected to emerge over the next decade. This forward-thinking infrastructure ensures that we stay ahead in the evolution of Web3.

We invite you to explore Verida DbStore through the interactive tutorial in our developer documentation and join us on our mission to empower users with self-sovereign identity and data.

Together, we can shape the future of Web3 and unlock its full potential.

Want to learn more? Join #dev-chat in our Discord community Check out the Verida developer docs Get started with Verida Partner with Verida and build with us Subscribe to our YouTube for more tech explainers, demos and more Follow and tag us on Twitter Subscribe to our mailing list and never miss a Verida update

Revolutionizing Web3 Storage: A Deep Dive into IPFS and Verida DbStore was originally published in Verida on Medium, where people are continuing the conversation by highlighting and responding to this story.

Circle Blog

How the USDC Reserve is Structured and Managed

USDC is built to always be redeemable 1:1 for the U.S. Dollar. It is a true bearer asset (like the cash in your pocket, but in digital form), capable of self-custody and transferrable to anyone, anywhere, at the high speed and low cost of the internet. It is imbued with the potential to transform financial services – lowering costs and increasing utility for billions of users. 

USDC is built to always be redeemable 1:1 for the U.S. Dollar. It is a true bearer asset (like the cash in your pocket, but in digital form), capable of self-custody and transferrable to anyone, anywhere, at the high speed and low cost of the internet. It is imbued with the potential to transform financial services – lowering costs and increasing utility for billions of users.

16:00 • a day ago

Horizen - Blog

Empowering the Horizen Community: The Zenvangelist Program and Its Impact

Communities play an important role in any blockchain and crypto projects. Community members became project ambassadors and were the first to spread the word about these new revolutionary technologies. In this article, see how Horizen leverages its community thanks to its ambassador program. Blockchain and crypto projects rely on their communities.  It is due to […] The post Empowering th

Communities play an important role in any blockchain and crypto projects. Community members became project ambassadors and were the first to spread the word about these new revolutionary technologies. In this article, see how Horizen leverages its community thanks to its ambassador program.

Blockchain and crypto projects rely on their communities. 

It is due to the precursory character of these technologies. They are too avant-garde for the mainstream media and too complicated for the general public. It took communities to be able to take an interest in emerging projects and to promote them more widely.

Take bitcoin, for example. One of its strengths is drawn from its original community, the cypherpunks. These are the best cryptographers in the world who helped the bitcoin technology emerge and have given it credit, as well as shedding light on revolutionary technology.

What is a (crypto) community?

Suppose we have a look at the definition of community. In that case, we find:

a unified body of individuals: such as the people with common interests living in a particular area  a group of people with a common characteristic or interest living together within a larger society a body of persons of common and especially professional interests scattered through a larger society

(source: https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/community) 

Crypto communities were born with people with shared crypto and freedom interests, living on the internet. They are linked by a shared policy (e.g., decentralization, banking freedom, currency sovereignty) but are still part of a larger society. Everybody can join the ownership by owning cryptos! And that’s the beautiful thing about it. 

Now that we know that the emergence of crypto and blockchain technologies is due to their communities, how do we use this strength by being a blockchain project?

The answer is with Horizen and its Zenvangelists!

The Horizen Ambassador Program

The Zenvangelists are active members form the Horizen community who are dedicated to contributing to and growing with Horizen.

 Zenvangelists are web3 believers from all walks of life who are passionate about Horizen. Anybody can become a Zenvangelist, as long as they are:

A part of the Horizen community. Interested in cryptocurrencies and blockchain technology in general Always willing to help other members of the community Eager to contribute to the growth of the Horizen community Want to be committed to continuous learning and education Be a self-starter (autonomous, self-taught, in short: passionate)

How do we empower our Zenvangelists?

We are always available for guidance and support We hold monthly meetings where they can discuss community matters and share ideas with the Horizen team and leadership Zenvangelists have exclusive early access to new Horizen product and service releases before the public We help Zenvangelists grow their personal network and reach, improve their skill sets, and provide event opportunities to represent Horizen. We reward Zenvangelists for their effort in many ways, including swagkit, ZEN rewards, free event participations etc. Some are Legends!

They are OGs, community, and project backbones or have joined us recently but have shown exceptional activity: let me introduce you to the Legend Zenvangelists.

Let me introduce you to our Zenvangelists: Mahnoor, our daily task moderator, PVM, our party organizer, DeFi-Money-Printer, our livestream host, Paragism, our technical writer and Xavier, our technologies tester and community teacher. 

We didn’t forget our OGs: Jonghun, Guan, Sidarta, and Psyrax.

Let’s get to know each of them a little more!

Why Horizen?

Mahnoor: In short, I chose Horizen because of its strong community, its innovative vision, and its potential to make a real difference in the world.

PVM: Mainly because of the privacy focus, constant development, and great potential. The innovating sidechains were giving new tools to developers, with $ZEN powering the future of DeFi, Play2Earn games, DApps, Web3, and NFT projects

DeFi: What first garnered my interest in crypto, as many like to joke about being “in it for the tech” was truly my growing interest in GPU mining. I’d tried to mine Ethereum at the time and had been failing with graphics drivers and related issues, so I found that ZEC was comparably profitable at the time and was easy to set up and get going.

When I found that Horizen would have the same algorithm and supply of coins, I saw opportunity at being an early supporter. The passion of the team at an early stage and to this day has always been something that stands out to me.

Xavier: Horizen looked like a big project and has since grown even bigger. There are 3 companies, a doxxed team, a news website, a blog, the academy, an open GitHub, the Horizen Early Adopter’s Program, and the HDE (Horizen Developer Environment). There are tools for the community: Discord, Twitter accounts, and Telegram channels … It even has a meme coin^^

There was a lot of work to build the Zendoo protocol, and since it was released, a new era has started, with Tokenmint and EON. I hope many sidechains will be added to the ecosystem in the coming months/years.

Paragism: The strong ethos of privacy attracted me initially. I also found Horizen very dedicated to bringing new innovations with its research-driven culture and strives to push technological boundaries. This blockchain project keeps delivering back-to-back developments with continuous R&D regarding various vital parameters to achieve high scalability and extendibility.

Michael: The project has a clear vision, excellent leadership, a capable team, unique technology, and major industry partners. Horizen ticks all the boxes, and with Horizen EON launching, we will soon see Horizen carve out its market fit.

Jonghun: At the end of 2017, while preparing for my own business, I wanted to learn more about the blockchain area. At that time, I found the ZenCash homepage and sent a direct email to send a proposal saying that I would like to work while learning.

We also asked for consent by presenting an article on zencash’s forum, which is now unused.

At the same time, I conducted various communication, such as sharing many conversations and Korean market research.

Based on that, I joined the current Horizen, and I strongly agree with the direction we are heading now, the role as a platform, and the cultivation of an ecosystem that focuses on practically necessary privacy such as Data-Privacy.

I first announced the launch of Horizen Korea at ZenCon0, and since then I have made preliminary contact with many partners for Horizen Korea in Korea.

Now that we are almost ready to announce the business outline and official launch, we will soon be able to meet Horizen Korea, which is taking on various challenges as much as the Korean community members expect of Horizen.

Guan: Because the project has a sustainable funding model and cool graphic designs. Horizen is an inclusive ecosystem where everyone is rewarded for their contributions.

For how long have you been in the Horizen community? Share your journey in crypto communities?

Mahnoor: I’ve been actively involved in the crypto ecosystem since 2019, and I’ve been passionate about the potential of blockchain technology to transform the way we live and work. Since then, I’ve been exploring different projects and communities in the space, and I was excited to join the Horizen team in late 2021.

As someone who has always been interested in the intersection of technology and finance, I was drawn to Horizen’s vision of a decentralized, privacy-focused ecosystem that empowers individuals to control their assets and data. I’ve been impressed by the team’s commitment to innovation and dedication to building a community-driven platform that can make a difference in people’s lives.

As a tracker of daily task submissions, I’ve had the opportunity to engage with Horizen users daily and see firsthand their enthusiasm and passion for the project. I’m honored to be part of such a vibrant and dynamic community, and I’m excited to see what the future holds for Horizen and the wider crypto ecosystem.

PVM: I joined the Zenvangelists in May 2021. I was expanding my reach into the Cryptoverse and was happy I could join the community. I was enhancing my blockchain knowledge, and Horizen was one of the chains that impressed me.

DeFi: I’ve been involved with Horizen since early 2017 very near the launch of the project when I first heard about it being supported on the first ever exchange for Horizen, Bittrex, which happened to be the first alt-coin exchange I had used in my crypto journey.

Xavier: I don’t remember when I first heard about Bitcoin, but at the time, I thought it was cooler to search for Alien life running SETI or help research with Folding@home than to mine cryptocurrencies.

I saw all this crash in 2018 and thought the ecosystem had turned to silly speculation.

But, after a while, during the bear market, I started looking into the ecosystem again and saw great people building interesting projects. I bought some cryptos and read a lot of whitepapers.

I started a website. The first tutorials I wrote were about Bitgreen and Zelcash (now Flux) configuration.

In 2020, I started looking into masternodes and Horizen was one of my first ones. A Secure Node was cheap, and the APY was very good before the halving.

I started to dig deeper into Horizen with the public release of Zendoo on the testnet, tested it on a VPS, completed some HDE tasks, and therefore wrote some articles.

Michael: Horizen was one of the first coins I bought when I started my crypto journey in 2017. I wasn’t active in the community then, but I used to lurk on Telegram. I was always impressed by how accessible the team was, and Rob was always in the chat, answering questions and engaging with the community.  His passion was infectious. During the 2018/19 bear market, I became more involved in the community. I tried to help where I could, such as live streaming the weekly team meetings, amplifying Horizen news through HorizenClips, and doing some end-of-year and zendoo launch community Livestream events.

Jonghun: I learned about Bitcoin from the end of 2015 and started mining with my computer at home. I didn’t get as much volume as the current Bitcoin whales, but I started to pay more attention to the technology called blockchain rather than profit.

Technically, it came out earlier, but the technology that was almost dead came back to the world through an example of Bitcoin, and since then, as new technologies such as Ethereum’s smart contracts have been introduced, the blockchain industry has begun to draw attention.

These days, diversity that can be utilized within the blockchain industry, such as NFT, is possible, but in the past, there were many people who took a business approach with a conceptual nature as a simple payment method. In it, I was obsessed with the thought of whether it would be right for someone to look into my wallet address, even though it is a wallet address made up of addresses that are very long and difficult for people to memorize.

From this point of view, even in terms of a simple payment method, we can see the importance of privacy.

Do you have something to say to those who want to join the Zenvangelist program or any crypto community?

Mahnoor: For those interested in joining the Zenvangelist program or any other crypto community, I would say: go for it! Being part of a community is a great way to learn, grow, and contribute to a larger cause. It’s an opportunity to meet like-minded individuals, share your knowledge and experience, and make a difference.

My advice would be to start by getting involved in the community in whatever way feels most comfortable to you. This could mean joining a Discord group, participating in social media discussions, attending meetups or events, or contributing to open-source projects. Whatever you choose, be sure to stay engaged, be respectful, and be open-minded. Everyone in the community is there to learn and grow; working together can achieve great things.

Finally, don’t be afraid to take on leadership roles and responsibilities within the community. Whether becoming a Zenvangelist, organizing an event, or contributing to a project, stepping up and taking action is the best way to make a real impact and show dedication to the cause. So, if you’re passionate about crypto and blockchain, I encourage you to get involved and join a community today.

PVM: The Zenvangelist Program, like the majority of crypto communities, empowers the users. You bring your skills, work with others, and learn. Being part of a strong, vibrant, and fun community will bring more knowledge than many courses.

DeFi: For any community members whether new or old my greatest advice to give would be to never underestimate the impact you may have on the communities and projects you are involved in, and in many cases opportunities will arise and those passionate community members certainly stand out of the crowd (and if not make sure you let yourself be heard in a constructive manner) a little effort goes a long way when we all work together to build something greater than one team or project can build alone.

Paragism: Horizen community is rich in resources. It will enable you to share personal relatedness and support the perpetual growth of the ecosystem. The sense of togetherness is profound and enjoyable here.

Xavier: Joining a crypto community is still the best way to learn about the ecosystem and a project.

The more you speak with people, meet others, and share what you know, the more your knowledge and comprehension grow. That’s a win-win. You become better and help others understand our ecosystem.

Michael: I say jump in! The Zenvangelist program is great because you can tailor it to suit your own unique talents! It is also a great way for you to get to know the team and community better, and it can help open lots of doors if you are pursuing a career in crypto.

Jonghun: Sure! In the Korean community, there are many valuable members who play many roles. For example, AstarZen is directly producing PFP NFTs for node operators in our Korean community. Needless to say, Ken is also the spiritual pillar of our Korean community.

Guan: We are an honest and lovely community with many interesting and smart people! Come on and join us, You won’t regret it!

How does it feel to be named Legend Zenvangelist?

Mahnoor: Being recognized as a Legend Zenvangelist within the Horizen community is amazing. Being acknowledged for my contributions and dedication is an honor.

I believe it helps promote the project, impart my wisdom and experience, and assist in adopting and engaging new users.

However, having the title of Legend Zenvangelist carries more obligations than just a title. It entails continuing to be involved and active in the community, sharing my knowledge and suggestions, and assisting in determining the project’s direction. It entails setting an example for others and motivating them to get involved and change the world.

Overall, being recognized as a Legend Zenvangelist is humbling, and it inspires me to keep putting in the effort and helping the Horizen community. I’m happy to be a part of this thriving ecosystem and eager to see what we can accomplish together.

PVM: I feel proud to be named a Legend Zenvangelist but still humble. It’s a title that makes me feel appreciated and the reason to keep working as hard as I did until now. Now I have to lead by example and maintain high standards

DeFi: It’s an honor to be recognized as Legend Zenvagelist, and my pleasure to see where the Horizen Ecosystem has come from, to where it is now, and being a part of where it is going. I truly believe the greater market is largely unaware of the constant building going on throughout the years and could be near the precipice of true recognition as a DeFi, Smart Contract platform – being secured by the largest node network and hybrid Proof of Work network structure under the hood.

Paragism: It is a matter of pride. Horizen community has empowered me to bring positive changes. I am grateful that my involvement and work have been recognised.

Xavier: That’s a funny bonus, but honestly, being called a legend wasn’t part of the plan when I joined the Zenvangeslists^^

Michael:  I feel a little undeserving because I have been pretty quiet in the community lately as I have been busy launching a new business in Seoul. But Horizen is definitely my favourite project!

Jonghun: I am delighted to hear that I have been selected among the valued Zenvangelists for more diverse endeavors. I am happy that I will work harder in the future with Horizen Korea as my new starting point, but I accept it with a heavy heart.

Guan: I feel so honored to be a Legend Zenvangelist, spreading Horizen is a significant thing in such a very early stage!  I also meet a lot of super cool ZEN-frens from all over the world. It’s a fantastic journey in my life!

Q: Mahnoor, thank you so much for being here every day for the community. You were even here during your maternity leave to help the fellowship. Where do you find this constant energy to be present in the community?

A: I believe that the crypto and blockchain space has the potential to revolutionize the way we think about money, data, and identity, and I’m committed to doing my part to help bring about that change. Whether it’s through tracking daily task submissions, answering questions in Discord groups, or participating in social media discussions, I always try to be available and responsive to community members.

Of course, there are times when it can be challenging to balance community involvement with other responsibilities, such as family or work. But ultimately, I believe that being present for the community is an important part of my role, and I’m grateful for the opportunity to contribute in any way I can.

Overall, my energy and enthusiasm for the Horizen community comes from my belief in its potential and my passion for the work that we’re doing. I’m honored to be a part of this dynamic and innovative ecosystem, and I look forward to continuing to contribute in any way I can.

Q: PVM, you are our event Zenvangelist and an excellent writer. So tell us, what is the best: hosting or participating in the party?

A: Hosting parties and events is fun, and taking part is even better. My friends tell me to make “PVM Entertainment and Leisure” a real thing, as the events I create are always top of the crop!

This is what I love to do … to create events that suit every crypto user, from NFT lovers to Crypt edges. I constantly think about new party activities and themes and ways to reward the participants with memories and good vibes”

Q: DeFi, you are the new Horizen community voice. You have great skills in hosting and green screen management. What came first, the desire to play with editing software or to talk about the Horizen project entertainingly?

A: AI would say my desire in content, editing, and feeling though I have an above average understanding of many concepts that others may benefit from all to tie in together, but to answer which came first, it was the tinkering around while bringing some creativity to the mix – I’d been doing so since the Windows XP era on Windows Movie Maker… Although the quality and effort was poor at best, I always try to make incremental improvements over time (even if it means two steps forwards, one step back at times).

Q: Paragism, what is different in the Horizen community?

A: The Horizen community gives a sense of belonging. All ideas are welcomed and we get to see plenty of expressions. The community members also get to learn new things and hone their skills.

Q: Xavier, you are the always-willing-to-try-tech-things-guy among the Zenvangelists. You make great tutorials and create love, hug, and cakes in our tokenization platform and EVM. Where does this genuine willingness to share come from?

A: I love tech. I love to learn new technologies. I started coding at 7 and never stopped learning different flavors of basic (Turbo) pascal, c, c++, java, SQL, HTML, javascript, php, tcl, … and systems administration.

I’ve been sharing my knowledge since 98, I think. It was one of my end of studies projects to write a website generator in java (v1.0.2) and use it to generate a website. The website was called Alaide (that means“help needed” in French). It was a collection of tutorials about HTML 3.2, CGI programming, and java.

I then wrote articles for the French Linux magazine for several years, mainly about Linux development.

I spent a lot of time browsing the apache forums and community websites like “léa Linux” or “le site du zéro.”

Nowadays, I work as a freelance sysadmin and developer and help my customers understand and face their tech problems. I’m still writing tutorials, helping people on Twitter and Discord, testing things, and helping people in their crypto journey.

Q: Jonghun, you’re more than the Korean community backbone; you made it to the Horizen team! What made you stay at Horizen through the years?

A: I have had various experiences within the blockchain industry.

I helped launch a global exchange in Korea and played the role of COO, and I am advising on various projects.

Unlike many projects, Horizen always develops by clarifying the vision set in the beginning, responding to the market, and knowing how to adapt.

From a currency with a simple privacy function, now as a platform, we are expanding the ecosystem for various projects. Of course, we are preparing to support the use of the Privacy function where it is actually needed, rather than abandoning it.

In the Korean community, not only me but Ken and so many people are moving together.

Maybe not just community members, but each of them speaks a lot about Horizen’s development direction in a really logical and passionate way.

There was also strong support from the community about removing the shield pool from the main chain this time. When voting on this, members of the Korean community debated day and night.

In addition to my vision for Horizen, Horizen, with such a passionate community, will keep everyone in the future.

Q: Guan, You are an OG who did much for the Horizen community. What made you stay through the years?

A: The team always knows how to push things forward. the project’s core cross-chain protocol Zendoo solves scalability that can massively help many web2 businesses into web3.

Horizen inspired artwork from Zenvangelist Sidarta0

“I love the sleeping astronaut. A lot. But also Topsy Turvy, one of the first artworks that got people from Horizen further interested in letting me have art on their products. I still have the original; it blows my mind that no one has ever bought it. I love the colors and the weird randomness. It was created in the flow. One of my favorites. Because I still remember the process. It was a fun piece to do. And also very hard to do again.”

Last but not least, special thanks to Psyrax, JC, our Legend Zenvangelist SupportMan, who is always available to assist the community with any node/mining-related questions. You’re the backbone of our Discord server, essential to the community. So, thank you!

Do you want to join the Horizen Ambassador Program and become a Zenvangelists? Visit this page to apply.

How to get involved without being a Zenvangelist?

Become a #ZenFren and participate in the #daily-tasks channel on Discord to be rewarded for being active in the community.

Join the Horizen Early Adopter Program to test new products before public releases

The HCC’s goal is to bring more decentralization into the Horizen project.

ZenIPs are meant to push improvement proposals to the greater Horizen ecosystem.

Horizen social media channels:

Horizen (@horizenglobal) / Twitter 

Horizen Discord

Facebook – LinkedIn – YouTube – Medium – Instagram – Github – Reddit 

The post Empowering the Horizen Community: The Zenvangelist Program and Its Impact appeared first on Horizen Blog.

Zcash

ECC Transparency Report for Q3 2022

Why release a transparency report? Electric Coin Co. is committed to openness and transparency — as we help evolve and […] The post ECC Transparency Report for Q3 2022 appeared first on Electric Coin Company.
Why release a transparency report?

Electric Coin Co. is committed to openness and transparency — as we help evolve and support the Zcash digital currency, and in support of our mission to empower people with economic freedom. This transparency report details company income, expenses, and use of funds during Q3 2022.

Key takeaways

Bootstrap received coins at a value below the ECC operating-expense level for Q3 2022. During this time, Bootstrap received coins at an average of $461,000 a month (at the Q3 average ZEC price, $60, for each of the three months’ distribution dates), and Bootstrap and ECC incurred average monthly expenses of approximately $766,000.  At the end of Q3 2022, Bootstrap and ECC collectively held approximately $3.0M in USD and approximately 116.9K ZEC.  As of March 16, 2023, the company held approximately $1.3M in USD and approximately 110K ZEC. 

Read the full report.

The post ECC Transparency Report for Q3 2022 appeared first on Electric Coin Company.

Zcash Foundation

Zebra as a package in the Arch User Repository

Marek Bielik introduces the new Zebra package for Arch Linux. The post <strong>Zebra as a package in the Arch User Repository</strong> appeared first on Zcash Foundation.
by Marek Bielik

We could start this post by saying that our motivation to create a Zebra package for Arch Linux was that Arch enjoys the highest average rating of any Linux distribution on DistroWatch. However, the truth is that one of our engineers uses Arch (btw.), and he thought it would be handy to have Zebra packaged.

Packages in the official Arch repositories contain compiled binaries signed by their maintainers. The Arch developers maintain essential packages, and so-called trusted users maintain the rest. In addition to the official repositories, the Arch User Repository (AUR) lets anyone from the Arch community share their own package. The difference is that AUR packages do not contain binaries but a script that pulls, builds, and installs the software for the user. Arch users are encouraged to inspect the script’s content before executing it.

Zebra is currently packaged in the AUR. The package prepares dependencies, pulls Zebra’s source code from GitHub, and builds and installs the same binary as the official Docker image.

AUR users can vote for a package to increase its popularity, and trusted users can adopt popular packages and promote them to the official repositories. As the ArchWiki says, “a good number of new packages that enter the official repositories start in the AUR”. The original zcashd node already has an official package, and Zebra will hopefully follow. So if you are, by the way, using Arch, feel free to install the zebrad package and let us know how it went on our Discord, or on the Zcash Community Forums. 

The post <strong>Zebra as a package in the Arch User Repository</strong> appeared first on Zcash Foundation.

bankless

164 - The FBI Agent Who Took Down the Silk Road with Chris Tarbell

Chris Tarbell is a former FBI Agent specializing in cyber investigations. While at the FBI, Chris led some of the most high-profile cybercrime investigations in the world, including the arrest of members of the hacker group LulzSec, as well as the founder of the Silk Road, Ross Ulbricht, which resulted in the largest seizure of bitcoins to date. ------ ✨ DEBRIEF | Unpacking the episode: 

Chris Tarbell is a former FBI Agent specializing in cyber investigations. While at the FBI, Chris led some of the most high-profile cybercrime investigations in the world, including the arrest of members of the hacker group LulzSec, as well as the founder of the Silk Road, Ross Ulbricht, which resulted in the largest seizure of bitcoins to date.

------ ✨ DEBRIEF | Unpacking the episode:  https://www.bankless.com/debrief-the-fbi-agent-who-took-down-the-silk-road    ------ ✨ COLLECTIBLES | Collect this episode:  https://collectibles.bankless.com/mint 

------ Rarely do we have the opportunity to pick the brain of a cybercop, but this was our opportunity to see through the eyes of the FBI agent who took down the Silk Road in the largest crypto seizure ever recorded.

In today’s episode, Chris shares the story of crypto, Ross Ulbricht, and the Silk Road as told by the FBI agent who took it down. We also dig into the eternal cat-and-mouse game between Cybercriminals and Cyberpolice, how to protect yourself from people who want to take your crypto, and if the FBI wants your private keys, how they get them. 

------ 🚀 JOIN BANKLESS PREMIUM:  https://www.bankless.com/join

23:53 • 4 days ago

Wrench in the Gears

Question From The Labyrinth – What About These Formative Assessments We’re Seeing In The Czech Republic?

The following is a correspondence from a teacher and father in the Czech Republic. I very much appreciated his observations, and he generously permitted me to share them with you all here in the hopes that it might help others. March 23, 2023 Hi Alison, I have been following your research for a certain time [...]

The following is a correspondence from a teacher and father in the Czech Republic. I very much appreciated his observations, and he generously permitted me to share them with you all here in the hopes that it might help others.

March 23, 2023

Hi Alison,

I have been following your research for a certain time now. I work as an elementary public school teacher, and there are some quite dramatic changes in the approach to students being implemented in our public school system. Nothing is official though. NGOs are starting to infiltrate the schools, such as the one I teach in. So far, this has taken the form of seminars for all teachers staff, where they stress student sovereignty, which is reasonable in essence. I have studied Montessori and Waldorf school methods and raise my own kids in such a way.

A method being pushed for about two years is called formative assessment. After taking the time to take a course on it and study it more thoroughly, I’ve found aspects of reductive scientific techno vision. Kids are given aims to fulfill along with some criteria they must meet at the end. When they finish working, they assess themselves according to the criteria and draw their conclusions about their own study. However, kids are unable to take their own studies into their own hands and be “responsible for it,” which is the underlying idea of formative assessment. It seems to me that it copies the fundamentals of machine learning, which they are trying to implement in our schools. I have tried it in many classes, and it is unrealistic, unnatural, time consuming, and unwanted by the kids.

Have you come across formative assessment in your country? Is it something they promote there also? Is this a method used to teach kids constantly sitting in front of panels and Ipads? I tried to find some studies supporting its success in teaching but found nothing. It is being promoted by the EU and our government all through our school system. As a teacher and a father I am concerned.

I also want to thank you for your research and the energy you are putting into informing people about these huge changes in our lives. Here, in my country, there is absolutely no information about the metaverse, blockchain, or AI whatsoever. Not even in blogs or social media.

I will be happy to hear from your opinion on this, should you find a minute. Keep up the good work! 

Greetings from the Czech Republic!

My reply: 

Dear Teacher Friend,

First, I think you are correct that it has everything to do with machine learning. The themes of “student-centered” education and “student voice and choice” have been central here for the past decade. While to the uninformed these ideas sound empowering, especially after so many years of drill and kill exercises for standardized testing that were intended to sap student and teacher creativity and curiosity. They know this. The program of “formative assessment” is in alignment with training a machine. It is goal oriented behavior. You can see numerous references to “formative assessment” in this 2012 OECD document for the Czech Republic promoting competency based education. 

If you want to better understand the evolution of competency-based education in the United States, here is a search of the term from my blog. I was introduced to these ideas by my friend Emily, a second grade teacher in Maine. She discontinued her blog a number of years ago, but some of the posts are available on the Wayback Machine – here and here. We didn’t know anything about machine learning at the time, just the human capital finance part.

Competency Based Education, which is sometimes called Mastery or Proficiency-Based, is a set up for digital skills badges and “lifelong learning” on the blockchain ledger. Essentially, the “self-directed” model of education suits the need to treat humans as learning agents in complex simulations that will be used to forecast future global labor markets. It is important to understand that teachers are intended to be the vanguard in the adoption of these new technologies. Managing educators as “improve-able” digital human capital is also a planned global investment market. In the United States, they conditioned teachers first to accept behaviorist badges and digital micro-credentials as part of their “professional development,” so they would embrace the idea and promote the new paradigm to their students. I see that Erasmus and EduSTA are doing the same in the Czech Republic.

There is a reason Jeff Bezos, grandson of DARPA and Department of Energy big-wig Lawrence Gise, is investing in Montessori pre-k. I didn’t know about embodied AI and sensor networks when I wrote this post. Look up RSF Social Finance, the Rudolf Steiner Foundation, now based in Silicon Valley. It’s a social enterprise channeling considerable amounts of tech money. No surprise then that, at least in the US, Waldorf schools forced masking of children. We have to be mindful that even “alternative” types of learning styles like Montessori and Waldorf are being set up to harvest data on children. This will happen through artificial vision cameras, beacons, sensors, and wearable tech installed in learning environments. Such environments can be in non-traditional classrooms and even the outdoors. 

What is most needed now is data to train artificial intelligence in social relations and human creativity and introspection. Formative assessments, when fed into a machine, allow the thinking process of the child to be made available for computation and analysis. This isn’t about one child or a classroom of children, but learning at scale – all of the children in the EU. It’s about the mental states of individuals and communities for the purposes of documentation and pattern recognition over time. 

A challenging task is to embody artificial intelligence. When the AI comes into the material world it has to be able to navigate with a material “body” around complex obstacles and changing environments. Much of this research has been conducted as part of the RoboCup – robotic soccer team competitions. That project is being led by Peter Stone at UT Austin in Texas. Stone is also head of SONY AI North America. 

All of this relates to choice and decision theory. Researchers use simulation modeling to train the AI before putting the technology into a robot. Within the digital simulation, the robots experience many failures moving through their test environment. Those failings affect their choices the next time around. Eventually, they “learn” to be more functional. 

I think it’s useful to see alternative “student directed” approaches to learning in this light. They will want children to be independent to the verge of social isolation to create the stress to force their decision making process – then log the self-reflection inquiry. This is “goal oriented behavior.” It is easier for the system to “learn” from disaggregated agents than a complex mass of humans collaborating, at least at this point. Some day, perhaps soon, the machines will be able to look at group dynamics with the same ease. It seems the Czech government has been very involved in the development of digital identity and e-government. Social Finance has also been working with the European Social Catalyst Fund to investigate pay for success opportunities in your country. Education and health are the two primary targets.

Thanks so much for reaching out. I hope you, and others, find this information helpful.

Sincerely,

Alison McDowell

 

23:01 • 4 days ago

This is our third episode in a series of conversations. To get the full debate you’ll need to listen to the last two episodes with Balaji Srini

There are bank runs and also rumors of more bank runs on the horizon. One side says, “the banks are insolvent, get to the lifeboats.” Another side says, “the banks are going to be fine…we’re sick and tired of doomers pulling the fire alarm.” Who’s right?

This is our third episode in a series of conversations. To get the full debate you’ll need to listen to the last two episodes with Balaji Srinivasan and Arthur Hayes.

20:46 • 5 days ago

Zcash

Update: Addressing Zcash wallet performance issues

Electric Coin Co. (ECC) has been working since June to resolve Zcash wallet performance issues that are affecting users of […] The post Update: Addressing Zcash wallet performance issues appeared first on Electric Coin Company.

Electric Coin Co. (ECC) has been working since June to resolve Zcash wallet performance issues that are affecting users of third-party apps Edge, Nighthawk, and Unstoppable.* All three of these mobile wallets utilize the ECC SDK.

Our engineers have made progress, however, work remains — including further updates to zcashd, lightwalletd, the ECC wallet SDKs, and the ECC prototype wallet — to fully restore good user experience in the impacted apps.

Solving these issues is our No. 1 priority, even taking precedence over our long term roadmap. Internally, we are calling this “Emergency Mode.” 

The syncing problem

Starting in June 2022, the Zcash network began experiencing a huge increase in shielded transaction volume. This additional network load caused a “data pileup” that prevented some wallets from being able to sync in a reasonable amount of time. (The current wallet sync process requires scanning the entire blockchain before funds are available to be spent.) If a wallet won’t sync, a user can’t access or spend their funds. 

It’s a complicated challenge to address, and at minimum, it requires developing and implementing (1) a faster algorithm that does not require a linear sync of all blocks on chain and (2) tooling modifications that will give users the ability to spend funds without having a fully synced chain. As mentioned, the solution comprises changes to every component in the shielded mobile wallet stack: zcashd, lightwalletd, the ECC wallet SDKs, and the ECC prototype wallet.

What we’ve done so far

Within weeks of identifying the problem, ECC released two updates to zcashd that resolved full node issues, and work was underway on the SDKs. In October, we released zcashd 5.3.0 to fix out-of-memory issues, but further public releases specifically relevant to these syncing issues were delayed, as ECC engineers were pulled off task to build zcashd 5.3.3 and 5.4.2 — critical updates that remediated vulnerabilities inherited from Bitcoin Core.

Here’s a summary of what we’ve done, so far, to address wallet performance issues: 

Released zcashd 5.1.0 and 5.2.0 in July to address performance in full nodes Released zcashd 5.3.0 to fix a number of intermittent out-of-memory issues Completed most of the code updates and testing for zcashd 5.5.0, which implements fee changes. Note: users should have the ability to spend funds without a full wallet sync upon the release of zcashd 5.6.0. Completed a portion of the back-end work required to support the next release of the iOS and Android SDKs, which will include the first phase of an improved sync capability. Exiting Emergency Mode

Our top priority is ensuring users can access and spend their ZEC (Zcash coins). This is fundamental to our mission of economic freedom and a requirement for real-world private digital cash.

Speed and reliability are also critical to Zcash user experience, so we’re building updates that will allow users to receive and spend new incoming funds faster,** and we’re implementing features that provide visibility on syncing progress.

Only after these capabilities are delivered — and when we’re confident that wallets are not being impacted by frequent crashes or inconsistent behavior — will we consider exiting Emergency Mode and widening our focus to include other initiatives.

The table below represents an estimated release schedule to address the wallet syncing issues. Each release is slated for delivery within a half-month window to allow for dozens of inherent dependencies. Interim releases may occur based on specific requirements or dependencies throughout this process. Version numbers listed may also change based on emergency or other unplanned impacts.

It’s important to note that after these releases are made available, third-party developers may need a number of days or weeks to implement and test.

DateReleaseDetailsFirst half of April 2023zcashd 5.5.0A transaction-fee structure change based on overall size (inputs/outputs) and frequency of transactions (ZIP-317) will make attempts to spam or flood the network with txs much more expensive and unlikely. Mobile wallet users sending regular single recipient transactions will not be affected by this change.

Fund availability improvement will provide the ability to spend funds before a wallet is fully synchronized. 

While this release will have no immediate positive effect on the wallet user experience, this is a necessary step toward exiting emergency mode.Second half of April 2023lightwalletd 0.5Partners currently running lightwalletd servers will need to apply this update to allow the future SDK capabilities to properly function and deliver an improved user experience via the mobile wallets.

Supports future zcash 5.6.0 update.Second half of AprilECC prototype walletThis initial version of the app is being developed with a minimum feature set as a test platform to validate current Zcash functionality and serve as a prototype for future feature development.

Initial distribution will be limited with a broader product launch later in 2023.Second half of May 2023zcashd 5.6.0DAGSync capability, which will enable fast sync and scanning of the blockchain

Users will not see the changes to the UX until the SDK update 0.6 (outlined below) goes out.Second half of May 2023Mobile SDK updates 0.6 (iOS & Android)This update will include support for third-party app access to fund availability and improved sync capabilities.

Once this update is live, it will be up to the individual wallet developers to integrate the new features into their application, which will enable users to access their funds without issues and improve the overall Zcash user experience. This will end the emergency mode.

* Based on community feedback, Ywallet has been working well and appears to be unaffected by high transaction load on the network.

** The speed benchmark we’ve set for downgrading from emergency mode is that a typical Zcash user can receive and spend funds at a rate of a month’s worth of transactions in one hour. This is not a perfect measurement (use cases can vary wildly), nor is it our end goal (we know a great user experience demands more), but we believe it’s important to set a reference goal for internal and community alignment. Future speed improvements will be planned once the critical issues are resolved.

The post Update: Addressing Zcash wallet performance issues appeared first on Electric Coin Company.

RadicalxChange(s)

Shrey Jain: Applied Scientist at Microsoft Research Special Projects

Shrey Jain, an applied scientist at Microsoft Research Special Projects, speaks with Matt Prewitt on a very timely and topical subject: AI and – more specifically – the dangers it poses to the nature of natural human communication (“context collapse”). They take a deep dive into the current threats to privacy by expanding beyond the often discussed cryptographic sense into “privacy as contextual i

Shrey Jain, an applied scientist at Microsoft Research Special Projects, speaks with Matt Prewitt on a very timely and topical subject: AI and – more specifically – the dangers it poses to the nature of natural human communication (“context collapse”). They take a deep dive into the current threats to privacy by expanding beyond the often discussed cryptographic sense into “privacy as contextual integrity”, and the immediate opportunity to embed ethical guardrails into this ever-changing realm of generative AI through possible solutions of designated verified signatures in “plural publics”.

Shrey’s recently published paper co-authored with Divya Siddarth and E. Glen Weyl “Plural Publics” is linked in the episode notes.

Links & References: 

Georg Simmel and The Sociology of Secrecy and of Secret Societies John Dewey on The Public and Its Problems: An Essay in Political Inquiry on JSTOR Scamming in AI via The Washington Post - They thought loved ones were calling for help. It was an AI scam. "Privacy as Contextual Integrity" by Helen Nissenbaum Also see: Privacy in Context: Technology, Policy, and the Integrity of... (book) Jaron Lanier on How to Fix Twitter—And All of Social Media - The Atlantic AI Education - Will ChatGPT Kill the Student Essay? - The Atlantic Shrey Jain, Divya Siddarth, and E. Glen Weyl. “Plural Publics.” Edmond & Lily Safra Center for Ethics, Harvard University, March 20, 2023.

Bios:

Shrey Jain (he/him) is an Applied Scientist at Microsoft Research Special Projects. His research area is AI Security and Cryptography with a specific focus on information integrity in an era of generative AI. Shrey's work has been featured in CBC News, The Globe and Mail, Financial Times, National Post, CTV News, and the Toronto Star.

New Lending Protocol Boosts Optimism TVL

Deposits in Sonne Finance Have Quintupled Since Mid-February

14:57 • 5 days ago

Zcash Foundation

Visualize Zcash Blockchain Data with Zebra + Elasticsearch + Kibana

Alfredo Garcia describes a new Zebra feature to store Zcash block data in an elasticsearch database, which allows us to use Kibana to explore and visualize the data. The post Visualize Zcash Blockchain Data with Zebra + Elasticsearch + Kibana appeared first on Zcash Foundation.
by Alfredo Garcia

The Zcash blockchain history is big and rich—any block explorer application can just call RPC methods from a zcashd node and present the data in the desired way. Data analysis is hard in this context, on the one hand, you can just do what a specific application will allow you to do, or on the other hand if you need different visualization you have to create your own app.

As an alternative, we can export and index all block (header and transaction) data fields into an elasticsearch database and use Kibana as a front end to do some analysis.

The possibilities of data visualization are huge with Kibana and all we need to do to create them is to feed an elasticsearch database with valid JSON block data.

When the elasticsearch feature is enabled, each block is sent from Zebra into elasticsearch; this is in addition to saving the block in the internal rocksdb database. We can then guarantee Zebra’s correct ongoing functionality and storage in the desired external database at the cost of more hard drive storage and a longer synchronization time.

Once the data has been inserted into the database, the Kibana part is easy. It may be able to provide many answers to existential questions our community deserves to know, for example:

How many Orchard transactions have we had since its introduction? (Adoption) How many shielded coinbase transactions have we had since its introduction? (Adoption) How many Sprout transactions did we have in the last X period? (Deprecation) How many transactions per block have we had on average since the start of the blockchain? (Information) Which hours of the day are more transactions executed? (User distribution) What is the average size of a block or transaction? (Parameters) What is the distribution between Orchard, Sapling, Sprout and transparent transactions? (Information) And many, many others. The Zebra elasticsearch feature has only been tested on Testnet so far. Here is a guide on how to set it up; it is pretty easy. What I think is needed next: Deploy the Mainnet in the cloud Setup Kibana for listening to an external IP address. Optionally attach a domain name to it. Create and share Kibana usernames and passwords between people interested in creating visualizations Create dashboards with Zcash data Share links to visualization in forums, twitter, news, etc. (external users do not need Kibana access to see shared visualizations)
If you want to collaborate on any of these, please let us know by posting to the Zcash Community Forum!

The post Visualize Zcash Blockchain Data with Zebra + Elasticsearch + Kibana appeared first on Zcash Foundation.

14:52 • 5 days ago

Epicenter Podcast

Laurence Ion & Vincent Weisser: Vita DAO – From DeSci to Longevity Research

Scientific research & publishing are gruelling tasks that extend outside the scope of science itself. Centralised publications abound in archaic practices that span from submitting a paper to getting it peer-reviewed and finally published, process which may take even up to years. In addition, research requires funding from very early stages of pursuing an idea, all the way to its finality (i.e

Scientific research & publishing are gruelling tasks that extend outside the scope of science itself. Centralised publications abound in archaic practices that span from submitting a paper to getting it peer-reviewed and finally published, process which may take even up to years. In addition, research requires funding from very early stages of pursuing an idea, all the way to its finality (i.e. clinical trial or real-life applications). In TradSci (traditional science), funding is usually obtained once progress has already been achieved or when a startup has been formed.
DeSci (decentralised science) sets out to change this paradigm by funding early stage research via DAOs. When it comes to scientific publications, peer reviewing is also decentralised and incentivised, considerably speeding up the process. Moreover, contributions can be clearly retraced, avoiding false claims over IP, and the research itself becomes much more easily accessible and disseminated.

We were joined by Vincent Weisser & Laurence Ion, stewards of Vita DAO, to discuss the advantages of DeSci in general, and the progress of longevity research in particular.

Topics covered in this episode:

Vincent’s background and his interest in longevity Laurence’s background and his interest in biotech The purpose of DeSci Which science branch is better suited for DeSci How DeSci fixes contribution acknowledgement & incentive misalignment From research idea to startup via DeSci funding $VITA token utility Accelerating scientific publishing via DeSci How IP is attributed in a DeSci setting Project review and governance in Vita DAO

Episode links:

Vincent Weisser Laurence Ion Vita DAO Molecule DAO Vita DAO projects Molecule Bio DAO launchpad The Longevity Prize The Longevity Decentralized Review

This episode is hosted by Friederike Ernst & Meher Roy. Show notes and listening options: epicenter.tv/488

14:29 • 5 days ago

bankless

zkSync Era Mainnet Launch & NEW zkEVM with Alex Gluchowski and Anthony Rose

Alex Gluchowski is the Co-founder and CEO of Matter Labs and the creator of zkSync. Anthony Rose is the head of engineering at Matter Labs and has a background in software and machine learning. Prior to joining Matter Labs, Anthony spent a number of years in the industry building teams at SpaceX.  In today’s episode, the four talk about zkSync’s massive announcement, they’ve launched their

Alex Gluchowski is the Co-founder and CEO of Matter Labs and the creator of zkSync. Anthony Rose is the head of engineering at Matter Labs and has a background in software and machine learning. Prior to joining Matter Labs, Anthony spent a number of years in the industry building teams at SpaceX. 

In today’s episode, the four talk about zkSync’s massive announcement, they’ve launched their zkEVM to mainnet! They also delve into the engineering challenges, what zk unlocks, the difference between zkEVM vs Optimistic Rollups, what builders need to know, and of course…wen token?!
